description: From Middle English gridil, from Anglo-Norman gredil, variant of Old French greil, from Latin crāticulum, diminutive of crātis. Doublet of grill (“grid of wire”), from the same Old French and Latin sources.

entries.meaning: A stone or metal flat plate or surface on which food is fried or baked.
examples: Some people when making scones do not trouble to light the oven but use the frying pan: of course if you have a griddle it is better than oven or pan, but very few people possess this useful utensil.

verbs.description: griddle (third-person singular simple present griddles, present participle griddling, simple past and past participle griddled)
